channel.title: Golang Weekly
channel.description: A weekly newsletter about the Go programming language

item.title: ã€Making the Go module proxy happier using a LICENSE fileã€‘ä½¿ç”¨è®¸å¯è¯æ–‡ä»¶ä½¿GOæ¨¡å—ä»£ç†æ›´å¿«ä¹
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹569 â€” September 10, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Let's Look at Go's New Experimental API for JSON â€” Working with the Internetâ€™s most popular data exchange format is a fundamental, day-to-day task for most developers but Goâ€™s original json package had enough shortcomings to warrant an attempt at a â€˜v2â€™ which you can use, in experimental form, in Go 1.25. The Go team breaks down the entire story and the behavior of v2 here, but also seeks yourÂ feedback.

Tsai, MartÃ­, et al.

ğŸ’¡ Anton Zhiyanov has a more code-driven tour of what json/v2 offersÂ here.

Go with the Domain: DDD & Clean Architecture inÂ Go â€” For Go developers tired of enterprise patterns that don't fit. The Watermill creators show how DDD actually works in Go with code examples from a realÂ application.

Three Dots Labs sponsor

What the Go Proxy Has Been Doing â€” A few weeks ago, Ted asked What is the Go (module) proxy even doing? after he found it hammering his server. Heâ€™s since traded some emails with Russ Cox and discovered some curious things about the proxyâ€™s behavior, particularly around the contents (and/or lack of) of LICENSE files. This post from Russ Cox himself goes into even moreÂ detail.

Ted Unangst

IN BRIEF:

  • The YAML project, official maintainer of the YAML format, has forked and taken over maintenance of the yaml package.

  • ğŸ˜± Geoffrey Huntley had a single goal: force Claude Code to loop over and over till it built a 'Go like' language based around Gen Z slang, and so Cursed was born. It works, and can even compile to native binaries withÂ LLVM.

  • ğŸ¥ gocv-to-webrtc offers a demonstration of streaming live webcam video to a browser using GoCV for capture, FFmpeg for realâ€‘time encoding, and Pion WebRTC for transport.

Avoiding Common sync.WaitGroup Mistakes â€” WaitGroup is easy to misuse, but as of Go 1.25, the go vet tool has extra checks to prevent error-prone calls to WaitGroup.Add, and WaitGroup.Go helps avoid some problemsÂ altogether.

Jon Calhoun

Solve Go Bugs and Bottlenecks Quickly with AppSignal â€” Fix Go bugs and bottlenecks fast with AppSignal. Get clear insights and ship reliable code. Start your free trialÂ today.

AppSignal sponsor

ğŸ“„ Running Go-Written Tools in a Browser â€“ The ability to compile Go to WebAssembly opens up some fun opportunities on theÂ Web. Uros Popovic

ğŸ“„ 'GoLand Can Do That?' Ten Secret Superpowers You Might Not Know John Arundel

ğŸ“„ Exploring Concurrency Issues with Philosophers and Go Annis Souames

ğŸ“„ Why I Ditched Docker for Podman (And You Should Too) Dominik SzymaÅ„ski

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

ğŸ¤–Â Google Releases Genkit Go 1.0 â€” Genkit Go is Googleâ€™s own open-source AI development framework and itâ€™s now production ready along with a suite of ancillary tools targeting Go developers building LLM-backed apps (and not just using Googleâ€™s own models). Thereâ€™s an introductory tutorial to learnÂ more.

Gill and Balahan (Google)

Ergo 3.1: An Actor-Based Framework for Go â€” A Go-based implementation of ideas and design patterns from the Erlang world. v3.1 introduces a new cron-like scheduler, external process management, and improved testing capabilities. Full docsÂ here.

Taras Halturin

go-getter 1.8: Download Things from Various Sources with a URL â€” So itâ€™s just an HTTP client? Not exactly. A GitHub URL can become a git URL, local filenames work, S3, Mercurial and BitBucket URLs all work as expectedÂ too.

HashiCorp

GoferBroke: An Anti-Entropy Gossip Protocol for Distributed Systems â€” A minimal, high-performance â€˜gossipâ€™ protocol designed for embedding decentralized, eventually-consistent state into yourÂ apps.

Kristian Woodroffe

Kratos 2.9: A Go Framework for Cloud-Based Microservices â€” A â€œmicroservice-oriented governance frameworkâ€ built aroundÂ HTTP/gRPC.

Kratos

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

$100 off yearly Frontend Masters membership! 250+ courses, personalized learning path, workshops with devs from GitHub & Netflix. Sale ends soonÂ â†’

  • csv-go 3.0 â€“ A flexible and performant single-threaded CSV stream reader andÂ writer.

  • Anubis 1.22 â€“ Provides a proof-of-work challenge to 'weigh the soul' of incoming HTTP requests in an attempt to stop/slow down AIÂ crawlers.

  • Gum 0.17 â€“ Go-powered shell scriptingÂ utilities byÂ Charm. Now with support for adding visual padding to many of theÂ commands.

  • Viper 1.21 â€“ Config solution for Go apps supporting various file formats and environmentÂ variables.

  • Listmonk 5.1 â€“ Self hosted email newsletterÂ system (homepage).

  • graphql-go 1.8 â€“ GraphQL server with a focus on ease ofÂ use.

  • Hugo 0.150 â€“ The popular Go-powered static siteÂ generator.

  • fx 39.1 â€“ The powerful terminal JSONÂ viewer.

  • Air 1.63 â€“ Live reload for GoÂ apps.

ã€‘

item.title: ã€Benchmarking Go SQLite librariesã€‘åŸºå‡†æµ‹è¯•GO SQLITEåº“
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹568 â€” September 3, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

ğŸ˜Â A-go-ha! Gopher Hawaiian Shirt Patterns â€” Humor me for this item in the last gasps of summer! In 2023, Russ Cox worked with Renee French (the creator of the Go gopher mascot) to design and print some Go-themed Hawaiian shirts. Theyâ€™ve now made the patterns generally available in several colors. Christmas sweater patterns next,Â perhaps?

Russ Cox and Renee French

ğŸ’¡ Note that the shirt patterns, and the image above, are all CC-BY-4.0 licensed.

Testing Time (and Other Asynchronicities) â€” The official Go blog continues with its tour of new Go features, looking at testing/synctest, newly promoted to general availability in Go 1.25. If you need to write fast, reliable tests for concurrent code, this is aÂ must-read.

Damien Neil

Go Logs with Full Context inÂ Sentry â€” See Go errors, traces, and logs together in one view for complete production context. Debug faster without sifting through logs or switching tools. Find root causes faster, fix problems quickly, and keep your applications running smoothly withÂ Sentry.

Sentry sponsor

Default Methods in Go â€” Goâ€™s interfaces are simple but can be brittle, particularly when adding a method and having several existing implementations. Miguel digs into some of the limitations andÂ problems.

Miguel Young

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ” The latest version of CodeQL, used in GitHub's code scanning system, now supports Go 1.25.

  • Ron Evans of TinyGo has shared his slidedeck from GopherCon 2025 which gives an update on the TinyGo project generally. We look forward to the eventual GopherCon 2025Â videos!

The 9 Go Test Assertions I Use (and Why) â€” Building on an article we linked in issue 562 about avoiding assertion packages, Alex makes a case for his homemade assertions, as well as whether assertion functions are anÂ anti-pattern.

Alex Edwards

ğŸ“„ How Go Schedules Millions of Goroutines: A Deep Dive intoÂ GMP RealBlank

ğŸ“„ From Go Code to Container Image with Depot API Chris Goller (Depot)

ğŸ“„ How to Deploy a Hugo Static Site to Hetzner Alex Pliutau

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Benchmarking Different Go SQLite Drivers (Again) â€” A benchmark weâ€™ve linked to a couple of times has seen another update. As with any benchmark results, maintain a critical eye here, but the author found significant differences between the nine options in certainÂ scenarios.

Christoph Vilsmeier

Dedicated Postgres Performance Workshop for Your Team â€” Expert-led workshop on your Postgres database to tune slow queries. New to pganalyze with a large Postgres footprint? This is for you. RequestÂ today.

pganalyze sponsor

Announcing GoReleaser v2.12 â€” The popular Go-flavored release crafting tool introduces a new Docker integration, Docker image attestation, Makeself packaging support (to create packages that self-extract/run), Go 1.25, andÂ more.

Carlos Alexandro Becker

Surf: An Advanced HTTP Client Library â€” Has a focus on web scaping and API automation by attempting to impersonate desktop browsers, handle fingerprinting, HTTP/3 support, andÂ more.

enetx

zek: Convert XML into a Go Struct â€” We first linked to this eight yearsÂ ago.
Martin Czygan

  • GoQueue 0.2.1 â€“ Background job processing library, now with support for multiple queueNÂ backends.

  • Pebble 2.1 â€“ RocksDB/LevelDB inspired key-value database in Go. Used by CockroachDB under theÂ hood.

  • Garble 0.15 â€“ Obfuscation for GoÂ builds. Now with Go 1.25Â support.

  • gofumpt 0.9 â€“ A stricterÂ gofmt. Now based on Go 1.25'sÂ gofmt.

  • Revive 1.12 â€“ Fast, configurable, extensible, flexible linter forÂ Go.

  • Hugo 0.149 â€“ The popular Go-powered static site generator.

  • tview 0.42 â€“ Rich interactive widgets for terminal UIs.

  • sqlc 1.30 â€“ Generate type-safe Go code fromÂ SQL.

âœ‰ï¸Â  From the Inbox

For a variety of reasons â€“ not least taking a vacation in August (oops!) â€“ I have a backlog of fantastic submissions from people that I want to share separately:

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ Flappy is a Flappy Bird clone built in Go. It runs cross-platform but isn't Ebitengine based, instead using Prototype which uses Direct3D and OpenGLÂ directly.

  • ğŸ“˜ John Arundel has released a new Go 1.25 edition of his book, The Deeper Love of Go.

  • Making Games in Go: 3 Months Without LLMs vs 3 Days With LLMs is a fun look at one developer's experiences in developing two card games in Go using a variety of technologies.

  • mtlog is a library for producing logs that 'read like prose' but are also structured for machine use. Check out the examples.

  • AgenticGoKit is a new event-driven agentic AI framework, currently inÂ alpha.

  • Przemek Delewski wrote Observability in Go: What Real Engineers Are Saying inÂ 2025

ã€‘

item.title: ã€Go experiments with SIMDã€‘è¿›è¡ŒSIMDè¿›è¡Œå®éªŒ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹567 â€” August 27, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

Go Weekly

Container-Aware GOMAXPROCS â€” The official Go blog kicks off a promised series of posts on Go 1.25â€™s new features with a look at some tweaked container-aware behavior around GOMAXPROCS, whose default limits make sense on bare metal but can cause issues in containerÂ environments.

Michael Pratt and Carlos Amedee

Go Experiments with SIMD: Intrinsics Arrive on the dev.simdÂ Branch â€” SIMD is a key part of high performance in many workloads and while SIMD instructions can be used from Go assembly, this experimental branch of the Go toolchain brings AMD-flavored SIMD support directly intoÂ Go.

cherrymui et al.

Kubernetes Cluster Management in 100MB of RAM â€” Portainer is written in Go for speed and efficiency. Manage 200+ Kubernetes clusters from a single control plane using just 100MB of RAM. No bloat, no nonsense; just fast, lightweight cluster management, the GoÂ way.

Portainer.io sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Go is being increasingly used for building faster tooling in the JavaScript space (such as the Go port of the TypeScript compiler) â€“ the latest such project is Rslint, a TypeScript-first linter written in Go, as a high performance alternative to ESLint.

  • Socket's Kirill Boychenko looks at how a malicious Go module was exfiltrating credentials via Telegram.

Waitgroups: What They Are, How to Use Them and What Changed with Go 1.25 â€” Gone are the days of where you had to call wg.Add() and wg.Done(), thanks to the new wg.Go function in Go 1.25 that handles the increment and decrement of goroutinesÂ automatically.

Matheus Mina

ğŸ“º Building Ebitengine Games for Web Browsers â€“ A quick 3-minute introduction or you can read it in articleÂ form. Trevor Slocum

ğŸ“„ Fun with Go Slices â€“ A playful look into a fact of Goâ€™s slice appending behavior that caught the authorÂ out. Monique Mudama

ğŸ“„ Implementing Forth in Go and C Eli Bendersky

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Gonzo: A Go-Powered Realtime Log Analysis Terminal UI â€” A powerful, real-time log analysis terminal UI inspired by k9s. Analyze log streams with beautiful charts, AI-powered insights, and advanced filtering - all from yourÂ terminal. GitHub repo.

ControlTheory

Watermill 1.5: Library for Building Event-Driven Apps â€” A library for working with message streams (over numerous channels like Kafka, RabbitMQ, HTTP or even MySQL binlogs) to build event driven apps. GitHubÂ repo.

Three Dots Labs

Secure Your AI Agents So That You Can Protect Your Users â€” Whether you have a B2B or B2C use case, Auth0 is a full IdP that provides robust security like MFA and continuous threatÂ monitoring.

Auth0 sponsor

BemiDB 1.0: Postgres Read Replica Optimized for Analytics â€” A Snowflake/Fivetran alternative that connects to different data sources, syncs data in a compressed columnar format to S3, and lets you run complex queries using a Postgres-compatible analytical query engine. AGPL 3.0Â licensed.

Bemi

html-to-markdown 2.4: Convert HTML to Markdown â€” Actually parses HTML rather than just using regexes, so can handle a lot of interesting edge cases. It can be used both as a CLI tool or Go library. GitHubÂ repo.

Johannes Kaufmann

YARR: Yet Another RSS Reader â€” A feed aggregator written in Go but with a Vue.js-powered frontend. Runs from a single binary with an embedded SQLite database for simplicity and has a similar look/feel to something like Feedbin.

Nazar Kanaev

  • Wire 0.7 â€“ Compile-time Dependency Injection for Go. However, note that the project has just been archived by Google with any future development encouraged to take place via aÂ fork.

  • Goose 3.25 â€“ Database migration tool. Supports SQL and GoÂ functions.

  • Tcell 2.9 â€“ XTerm-inspired cell-based views for textÂ terminals.

  • Sarama 1.46 â€“ IBM's Go client library for ApacheÂ Kafka.

  • GitHub MCP Server 0.13 â€“ GitHub's official MCP server is written inÂ Go.

  • grype 0.99 â€“ A vulnerability scanner for container images and filesystems

  • gorush 1.19 â€“ A push notification server built onÂ Gin.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A roundup of other interesting stories from the broader developer landscape:

  • Sam Rose has put together a fantastic illustrated introduction to Big O notation. If you've ever wondered what O(1), O(log n), etc. mean, this is a great primer.

  • David Heinemeier Hansson, best known for his work on Ruby on Rails, has been building out his own Arch-based Linux distro/setup of sorts and has now released Omarchy 2.0 (here's a 30 minute video tour). It's been very popular with developers on social media recently.

  • ğŸŒˆ What is a Color Space? is a deep look into the 'unreasonably complex' topic of color and why, in digital realms, they can be represented in so many different ways, whether RGB, HSL, OKLCH, or others.

  • A thorough look into Postgres logging techniques for performance optimization.

  • An illustrated guide to OAuth.

ã€‘
>>>>>>>>>
é˜…è¯»Webç‰ˆæœ¬

portainer.io

  • goè¶Šæ¥è¶Šå¤šåœ°ç”¨äºåœ¨JavaScriptç©ºé—´ä¸­æ„å»ºæ›´å¿«çš„å·¥å…·ï¼ˆä¾‹å¦‚

  • æ’åº§çš„Kirill Boychenkoçœ‹ç€

Matheus Mina

  • Sam Roseå°†

  • David Heinemeier Hanssonä»¥åœ¨Railsä¸Šçš„Rubyä¸Šçš„å·¥ä½œè€Œé—»åï¼Œä¸€ç›´åœ¨å»ºç«‹è‡ªå·±çš„åŸºäºæ‹±é—¨çš„Linuxå‘è¡Œ/è®¾ç½®ï¼Œï¼ˆè¿™æ˜¯

item.title: ã€The one with the big Go 1.25 releaseã€‘å¤§GO 1.25å‘è¡Œ
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹566 â€” August 20, 2025

Read the WebÂ Version

â˜€ï¸ We're back from a week off â€“ the previous issue is here if you want to check it out again â€“ and we should now be back every week until October at leastÂ :-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

â­Â Go 1.25 Released â€” Sadly Go 1.25â€™s release coincided with my vacation â€“ what luck! Nonetheless, 1.25 is a solid release, focused on fixes, improvements, and tool upgrades, rather than language changes, making it an easy upgrade for most. Here are some of the highlights and further resources to checkÂ out:

  • The final Go 1.25 release notes provide all the details of the release.
  • A new, experimental garbage collector is available to try, behind the GOEXPERIMENT=greenteagc build-time option.
  • Anton Zhiyanov's Go 1.25 interactive tour remains a great way to get up to speed with the few language tweaks there are, including WaitGroup.Go(), the v2 JSON package, and the now-generally-available testing/synctestÂ package.
  • Microsoft has issued a release of its own Go 1.25.0 build and *TinyGo* has a Go 1.25 build too (more on that below).

Dmitri Shuralyov (The Go Team)

Take Control of User Roles and Permissions â€” As your app grows, hard-coded roles and permissions become messy and slow development. WorkOS RBAC makes it easy to define roles, group permissions, and manage access at scale with simple APIs, a powerful dashboard, and native SSO and SCIMÂ integrations.

WorkOS sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Amazon Web Services has created an 'Advanced Go Driver' for Amazon RDS and Aurora that wraps pgx or the native MySQL driver to provide enhanced functionality, particularly around auth and switchover/failoverÂ scenarios.

  • Embedded Go is a Go toolchain that adapts the Go compiler to target alternative devices including the Raspberry Pi Pico 2 and even the NintendoÂ 64.

  • ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ Jamie Tanna shares a detailed writeup of his experiences at last week's GopherCon UKÂ 2025.

D2: A Declarative Diagramming Tool in Go â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Mermaid, this is a similar idea but built in Go. Itâ€™s a powerful tool, and has become even more so this week with support for ASCII outputs, so you can use your diagrams in even more places. GitHubÂ repo.

Terrastruct

What is the Go Proxy Even Doing? â€” Goâ€™s module proxy provides stability for developers, but its design can hit upstream servers with redundant clones. Ted shows the logs and explains how he defends hisÂ server.

Ted Unangst

ğŸ“„ From Python to Go: Why We Rewrote Our Ingest Pipeline â€“ They started with Python for faster prototyping but rapidly saw huge gains after shifting toÂ Go. Telemetry Harbor

ğŸ“„ Understanding Go Error Types: Pointer vs. Value â€“ â€œThe subtle distinction between pointer and value error types can silently break yourÂ code.â€ Fillmore Labs

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Introducing gomjml: MJML Email Markup for Go Developers â€” MJML is a framework for writing emails using special, custom HTML tags which then get transformed into safe, responsive HTML that notoriously touchy email clients can handle. MJMLâ€™s main implementation is for Node.js, however, but Preslav has built a new, Go-nativeÂ approach.

Preslav Rachev

TinyGo 0.39: Now with Go 1.25 Support â€” TinyGo is a popular Go compiler that takes Go to â€˜small placesâ€™ like embedded systems, microcontrollers and WebAssembly use cases. v0.39 is a bigger release than it sounds as it brings Go 1.25Â support.

Ron Evans et al.

How to Boost Your Kubernetes Security with Smart Add-On Management â€” Learn proven strategies to identify risks, meet compliance, and streamline add-on updates in our K8s securityÂ guide.

Fairwinds sponsor

The 5 Best Logging Libraries for Go â€” An opinionated, but potentially useful, list.

Vadim Korolik (LaunchDarkly)

Go-edlib: String Comparison and Edit-Distance Algorithms â€” Levenshtein, LCS, Hamming, Damerau levenshtein (OSA and Adjacent transpositions algorithms), Jaro-Winkler, Cosine, and more make an appearanceÂ here.

Hugo Bollon

  • Ginkgo 2.24 â€“ Mature testingÂ framework. A new semantic versioning filter has been added so you can run specs based on versionÂ constraints.

  • Mongo DB Driver 2.3 â€“ The official Go driver forÂ MongoDB. Go 1.19+ is now required, and this is the final release to support MongoDBÂ 4.0.

  • River 0.24 â€“ Robust job processing system for Go andÂ Postgres.

  • graphql-go 1.7 â€“ GraphQL server with a focus on ease ofÂ use.

  • Ristretto 2.3 â€“ High performance memory-bound Go cache.

  • NATS.go 1.45 â€“ Go client for the NATS messagingÂ system.

  • go-zero 1.9 â€“ Cloud-native Go microservicesÂ framework.

  • golangci-lint 2.4 â€“ A faster way to run GoÂ linters.

  • Dynamo 2.4 â€“ Expressive DynamoDB library.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ Scale sub-ms speed. Redis 8.2 pushes 1M+ ops/sec. Deploy for free and stress-test it in your ownÂ stack.

ğŸ˜ Postgres user? Be sure to check out our sister newsletter, Postgres Weekly.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A roundup of other interesting stories from the broader developer landscape:

  • GitHub's CEO, Thomas Dohmke, has stood down and with it, GitHub has been rolled into Microsoft's 'CoreAI' organization more completely.

  • If you've never quite got your head around SVGs (Scalable Vector Graphics) and how paths are defined in them, Josh W Comeau has a new, fantastic guide to SVG paths.

  • Redis 8.2, the latest version of the popular data structure store/database, has been released. Over 70 commands now run faster than in Redis 8.0 and I/O threads now enable significant concurrent performance gains. Some neat memory usage reductions featureÂ too.]

  • GitHub's Taylor Blau shares some highlights from this week's GitÂ 2.51Â release.
